comments.author: Jordi Posthumus

comments.text:
Not a replacement for Electric Vehicles, but a great way to extend the 
usefulness of the existing infrastructure based on hydrocarbons. The major 
drawback of improving the internal combustion engine is that it is an 
obsolete technology, akin to making the most efficient coal fired steam 
engine.
The flexibility of storing breaking energy through the use of a compressed 
air storage tank is a brilliant move, better than 1st generation electric 
hybrid vehicles, but not as good as current plug-in hybrids. 
It would be great if technology is applied to commercial vehicles and 
marine engines that do not lend themselves to energy stored in batteries.
comments.author: Terrence Lee Reed

comments.text:

comments.text:
+Chase Prollock nah, it'll make more, 450hp is what a built FR-S/BRZ motor 
can pull when tuned properly, id reckon a little more power and TQ but a 
more efficent and better engine all around
comments.author: danknasty661

comments.text:
+Stephen Bagnell I believe it. Doesn't take much to punch a hole in a 
piston moving at 7000 rpm.
comments.author: Chase Prollock

comments.text:
+Chase Prollock
Valve clearance is a big issue.
I lost a 327 v8 because of a floating valve
comments.author: PC Master Race

comments.text:
+Stephen Bagnell True. I was wondering that myself. Basically the valve 
would have to wait for the piston to be completely clear of the valve 
before opening, rather than opening right after the piston passes TDC. 
Unless they can somehow control the speed at which it opens, using 
different air pressure, but that gets extremely complicated and still not 
even sure it's possible. But it is still an improvement over what we have 
currently. But another thought is, if they design it on an engine that is 
not an interference engine (Meaning the piston never crosses the path the 
valve takes), for example, dips in the top of the pistons for valve 
clearance, then they could REALLY squeeze some power out of any engine.
comments.author: Chase Prollock

comments.text:
+Chase Prollock
Only thing i would worry about is valve to piston clearance.
That technology opens valves instantly.
comments.author: PC Master Race

comments.text:
+Stephen Bagnell I can too! I have a Scion FR-S and with this design, I can 
imagine factory, 260 hp. And with an aftermarket turbo, mildly tuned, 450 
whp easy. I love this design and would love to see it make it into 
production. As long as it's reliable. Worst case scenario should an 
actuator go out? Maybe the valve just won't open rather than drop into the 
cylinder. Surely they'll design a safety.
comments.author: Chase Prollock

comments.text:
+Chase Prollock
I can imagine a 10.0L V8 getting 25 mpg with a near zero valve lift.
comments.author: PC Master Race

comments.text:
It could make any engine efficient. Imagine motorcycle engines hitting

of time.

comments.text:
It has to be a car that sells. To sell the ideal car that is eco and 
efficient will need some serious R&D money. Does SAAB have that money? If 
it did would it spend on new technology?  SAAB went in for 4 cylinder 
turbos because it never had the money to make a new range of 6 cylinder 
engines - but turbos were existing and proven technology. Slapping a turbo 
on an existing engine did it. Maybe removal of the camshaft and its chain 
on an existing engine range, which not difficult to do using their existing 
block, will spur them on. Hopefully. Do expect to see this camless 
technology soon as makers like a good couple of years trial, with 
adjustments along the way, on a number of cars before saying "yes". Then 
the production lines have to be geared up for it. It all takes time.  And 
if a new management system has to be programmed to eliminate the 
transmission then even more time in trials, etc.

comments.text:
Car batteries haven't evolved because there wasn't any market for it. Now

anymore. Once you get to over 200 miles of range, as the Tesla S does, 
range is not an issue anymore. Recharging time remains one, but you can 
count on the industry creativity to find solutions. Check this: 
http://www.teslamotors.com/batteryswap

Pretty cool. Love Koenigsegg! Only issue is that the future of the internal

and MacLaren now incorporate electric motors in their cars and I'd give it

comments.author: Vincent Paquet

top_comment.text:
I keep coming back and watching this video over and over again to get 
pumped up for the future of car engine technology. Hopefully we get an 
update for this Free Valve system soon from mister Koenigsegg﻿
top_comment.author: maximus9401

comments.text:
+maximus9401
The valve timing is infinitely variable. They can not control how quickly 
the valve opens or closes. It's been researched and done over and over by 
people with the best engineers on the planet, with almost unlimited 
budgets. F1 teams tried it and abandoned it. Additionally, with this type 
of system, you can't vary the valve lift like Honda's VTEC or Toyota's 
Valve-Matic. Airflow doesn't like big lifts at low rpm. The whole problem 
with this type of valve actuation system is that it can't be optimized for 
all driving conditions. You need variable timing, variable lift, and 
ideally, a variable profile. The system here is 1D. The OEM's spend 
MILLIONS on 1 mpg. When we start applying litmus tests like this, it seems 
rather ridiculous. If one really wants to learn about it, like I said, 
there are papers available from SAE where you can read all about the 
technology, and the reasearch that's been done on it.
comments.author: MJRPerformance

comments.text:
+MJRPerformance but the thing is, it's infinitely variable so they don't 
have to use the square profile for the valves at low rpm. They can adjust 
it to whatever keep the AFR's safe and brings in torque, then adjust to the 
square profile under heavy load. It's simply a matter of computer tuning to 
get the valves to behave like they need to
comments.author: maximus9401

comments.text:
+maximus9401 You can go buy papers from SAE to read about it all day long. 
Nothing new here. The major manufacturers have already taken it way farther 
than this guy. Some teams in F1 have already tried it many years ago. At 
low RPM, airflow doesn't "like" the valve being opened quickly with a 
square profile. Good in a race engine, not in a daily driver. Big 
reliability problems, as well. For a no-strings-attached 30% gain in fuel 
efficiency, this would already be in every car on the road. Toyota spends 
hundreds of millions for a 1% gain, and they're at the leading edge for 
efficiency. 

Cheers.
comments.author: MJRPerformance

top_comment.text:

comments.text:
Not exactly the same, this system uses a central air pump and then 
distrubutes and controls air pressure to each valve. The Fiat system pretty 
much uses each came to pump oil which is controlled via electric computer 
controlled valves. Both systems are very cool, but this system is a bit 
more technologically advanced it seems.
comments.author: 51farmalla

top_comment.author: americanmusclecar100

comments.text:
Good point. Instead of having to optimize a street engine with a cam that 
is decent on the low end and top end as well, this sort of camless design 
would allow for optimal lift and duration at any RPM, so in a new Coyote 
5.0 for example, you could have a minimum of .300 valve lift at cruising 
speeds, but the lift and duration increases as the RPM and air/fuel ratio 
changes, making for an extremely efficient 4v V8 that gets 30-35 mpg (or 
more?) and then turns into an insane race engine in which the valve lift 
increases in milliseconds to .500 lift, .600 lift, .700 lift and even 
further, spinning up to 10,000+ rpm, making power and torque curves beyond 
anything we've ever seen in a street car and producing probably over 200 Hp 
per liter naturally aspirated.
comments.author: 2013FiveOh

comments.text:
You would be able to adjust each valve on the engine individually and 
infinitely, same thing as going to individual coil packs vs the old style 
distributors. It's a simple and brilliant idea if you ask me.
comments.author: manfromwyoming

top_comment.text:
aaah, shame there is still the darn valve spring to compress... so valve 
operation losses are probably the same as a camshaft engine... but you gain 
alot by these variable valve timings.﻿
top_comment.author: Paxmax

comments.text:
In F1 they use compressed air to close the valve. The idea was that at the 
highest of rpm, especially when F1 engines reved to 18k+ they avoided valve 
float. Depending on what kind of rpm is required for this application, a 
coil spring might be sufficient. What is very important to get rid of, are 
the rocker arms and cams. Aggressive cam lobes can and will wear everything 
down. And as mentioned, the ramping of the lobes are very limited, 
especially if running self adjusting hydraulic lifters, whether it being 
OHC or OHV. You can run a very aggressive valve spring if you don't have to 
take cam lobes, cam drives and lifters into consideration.
comments.author: ABOlsen69666

comments.text:
+Austin Kiger He did mention in the video that the valves would still be 
returned by either a spring or compressed air. :)
comments.author: Disco Jesus

comments.text:
I think you misunderstood, or else I did. You'd do away with the camshaft 
and springs, and let the actuator open and close the valve.
comments.author: Austin Kiger

top_comment.text:
Koenigsegg has developed a system to completely replace the camshaft of an 
internal combustion engine with individual valve actuators. The result is a 
significant reduction in engine size, weight, and complexity while 
increasing power and torque. This could be a bigger deal than fuel 
injection.﻿
top_comment.author: Rob Speed

comments.text:
+Rob Speed yeah, this is truly amazing! Imagine koenigsegg doing this in 
the new one:1 while adding a 200 hp e-motor! 😮😮😮
comments.author: SAGE GOD MADARA

comments.text:
As someone who uses engine braking aggressively, the idea of an air 
compression hybrid sounds amazing.
comments.author: Rob Speed

top_comment.text:
at first when he said camshafts are limiting I thought, what about Vtec or 
VVT-I?  Then he showed the valve open/close profile and how a camshaft 
cannot replicate that.  Im not sure if I buy 30% gains in fuel millage, 
torque and power...but I can see how this tech would make improvements in 
all three.  And to do so while reducing the size and weight of an engine is 
impressive.  Just the reduction in rotating mass and friction will help 
engines perform better.  Some wont like giving the job of timing to a 
computer, but the adjustments that can be made on the fly could really 
improve how a car runs.  Modern "eco" and "sport" modes just change 
throttle response and transmission shift points...maybe some fuel mapping 
and ignition timing.  But changing the valve timing in ways you cant do 
even with modern variable valve tech should make a big difference.  Dang 
impressive.﻿
top_comment.author: RCPro Driver

comments.text: +Aidan Sharples Yeah and by then cars as we know may be very different
comments.author: Marco de la Peña

comments.text:
+Marco de la Peña Unfortunately that can never happen. If we burn only one 
fifth of the currently known oil reserves we will be at survivability 
tipping point. We have discovered an estimated 8% of total reserves. This 
means we will all be dead before we run out of oil.
comments.author: Aidan Sharples

comments.text:
I'm sure we will only see this technology when the world is almost out of 
oil
comments.author: Marco de la Peña

comments.text:
the cost for them to "build" a camless engine will be less.  but designing 
and tooling a full lineup of camless engines (4,6 and 8 cyl) would be 
expensive.  while people would surely buy cars with such engines and 
benefit from the new tech, car companies today don't show that they are in 
touch with what consumers really want.  they are going for flash and gizmos 
over affordable/reliable.
comments.author: RCPro Driver

comments.text:
in the long run that is true...but car companies tend to look more short 
term.  They will look and see they are making money on current technology 
and that tooling up for and designing their own camless engines would be 
costly.  Sure, it will pay off...especially if one of the big auto makers 
comes out with it before everyone else does.  Imagine if ford or chevy 
could suddenly offer a camless engine in most of their models.  They would 
have a advantage in every class in terms of power and MPG.  People have 
flocked to the ford ecoboost line because the MPG looks pretty good and you 
don't sacrifice power.  But imagine if you had a camless, DI, turbo charged 
4cyl engine to offer in your sedan lineup?  The gains from the ideal cam 
profile on a NA have been proven...imagine similar, if not better gains on 
a turbo charged engine!  But the fact is that car companies will hesitate 
to introduce a technology that would make ALL their current engines 
obsolete.
comments.author: RCPro Driver

comments.text:
+RCPro Driver you could make a lot more profit using camless. Building the 
engine would require less material costs because of the lack of a camshaft. 
And the engine would be smaller, requiring less room in the engine bay
comments.author: waysideme

comments.text:
I think it is less to do with the gas companies and more to do with the 
auto makers not seeing profit in it.  Or rather...why introduce such a huge 
advance when people are willing to pay big bucks for the current engines?  
It takes a lot of tooling and R&D to make a new engine.  The auto makers 
wont bother to invest that until they feel the consumer demands higher MPG 
and HP.  But currently, people seem impressed and satisfied by 30-40mpg 
cars.  The auto makers care far more about profit than advancement.
comments.author: RCPro Driver

comments.text:
I also share your thoughts on the massive domino effect of benefits this 
would bring, but I'm wondering why the hell big car makers haven't done 
that yet?, I don't think they hasn't think about it. In fact this does make 
one believe in petrol conspiracy
comments.author: Marco de la Peña

comments.text:
+上記に漂流
Yeah the hell with camless. When are they gonna phase out the wheels and 
give us rocket ships like they promised years ago? Oh well maybe I'll just 
order a 918 to hold me over. What end of the biz are you planning on 
getting into? I'm in racing... pushrod engines, so it's mostly drag, circle 
and offshore boats.
comments.author: wd1000

comments.text:
+wd1000 Thats a damn cool job. Im part way through my BEng in Automotive 
engineering, from what I can see it won't be too long until we start seeing 
camless valvetrains on road cars, you better watch your back!
comments.author: 上記に漂流

comments.text:
Hmmm. I design camshafts and I DO NOT endorse this system... at least until 
I retire haha. Actually I would love one of these systems to play with. 
It's potential is unbelievable.
comments.author: wd1000

comments.text:
I guess with this system you can effectively de-choke the engine (remove 
the throttle valve completely), as you can fully control the inlet with the 
valves instead of having to restrict the air flow with a throttle. This 
will massively increase the thermodynamic efficiency. Also you could not 
only change valve timing and lift but also valve duration which isn't 
really possible with mechanical VVT systems. Really cool shit eh?
comments.author: 上記に漂流

comments.text:
I honestly am really interested in seeing cars and motorcycles running on 
those engines.
comments.author: Doug Hardy

comments.text: Koenigsegg for president.
comments.author: Colin Scott-Fleming

comments.text: uh this rules
comments.author: Doug Hardy

top_comment.text: This is genius.﻿
top_comment.author: Daniel Rhyne

comments.text:
Koenigsegg is genius. My all-time favorite supercars, hands down. But 
seriously, cool tech! I like electric. A lot, in fact. But the sounds and 
feelings you get from tiny, perfectly-timed explosions are difficult to 
beat.
comments.author: Tim Rhyne

comments.text:
This guy is a real innovator. I'm looking forward to driving my first 
camless car!
comments.author: Peter Rhyne

top_comment.text:
I'm no engineer, but what about using an electric system or electric 
actuator of some kind instead of an air pneumatic system? I imagine air 
compression would be less efficient given the need to compress the air etc, 
but perhaps I am mistaken...﻿
top_comment.author: nimajneb02

comments.text:
Don't let people stop you when you have a good idea Nimajne02, You don't 
have to be an engineer to have a great idea. Just so happens that this 
system is controlled by "electro-pnumatic-hydralic" actuators.

from their website:
"Traditional Free Valve engines use either electro-magnetic, 
electro-hydraulic, or fully mechanical actuators to open the poppet valves. 
Instead of using these traditional actuator types, Cargine uses 
electro-hydraulic-pneumatic actuators combined with advanced sensor 
techniques. As a result, Cargine has overcome all of the typical challenges 
faced by other Free Valve techniques."
comments.author: Jerry Sollien

comments.text:
Good points, I wasn't aware of these. But how is the pneumatic system 
controlled? would it not be some form of solenoid to direct the air 
pressure in and out etc.?
comments.author: nimajneb02

comments.text:
There are a few current problems with electric actuators, they are heavy, 
they need large amounts of electricity which would add to the weight and 
complexity and they can't operate fast enough past a certain point which 
would make them useless in a gasoline engine.
comments.author: V12BigBlock

top_comment.text:
Eigentlich eine total naheliegende Idee.
Auf die ersten Motorrad-Motoren mit dieser Technologie bin ich auch sehr gespannt.
top_comment.author: Marco Bruchmann

comments.text:
aehm... ich meinte was das für ein Auto ist, aber das ist irrelevant da der

muß bleiben, sonst wusste ich nicht wie die Verbindung mit der Getriebe 
stattfinden soll :)) Auf jeden Fall, klingt mega-interessant :))

top_comment.author: ABOlsen69666

comments.text:
+ABOlsen69666 I don't think that the Veneno or LaF set themselves apart to 
be honest. I was referring originally to the current range of Ferrari and 
Lamborghini, which are in a different league compared to the superior range 
of Koenigseggs. Veneno is just a tuned Aventador (absolutely nothing wrong 
with that!) and the LaFerrari is a 458/Enzo with a an electric motor. 
However the LaF does have KERS as its merit, which is cool. Only 3 Veneno 
were made so that hardly counts as a "series". I just find the innovations 
that Koenigsegg have done/been part of are more substantial than what other 
have been up to. The Triplex suspension, 3G telemetry, Flexfuel system, 
free valve technology. The thinking that goes into making a car go and stop 
from 281mph has to be innovative.
comments.author: Timo E

comments.text:
+LJRossPhoto I know it's not proper form to answer a question with a 
question. But seen as you did not ask me, and in this case it would 
actually be very informative to know in which way, you think the Veneno and 
the LaF sets themselves apart compared to Koenigsegg, when it comes to new 
technology? And just to get it out of the way, the hybrid technology 
implemented by Ferrari is not new, and it was a choice from Koenigsegg not 
to go that route, not a could-not. And just to make it clear, this is not 
about hating on the LaF, I'm very impressed with it and like it. I just 
don't understand why you are saying what you are.
comments.author: ABOlsen69666

comments.text: +Timo E Really? The LaFerrari and Veneno aren't in the same league anymore?

comments.text:
+LJRossPhoto Ferrari and Lambo are not in that league anymore. Neither is

comments.text:

top_comment.text:
Amazing. I can see why they're hush hush about this, or rather, Were hush 
hush. They've been running this system in a car for 3 years now, perfecting 
it. 

Worth a watch, but the Too Long Didn't Read version: Instead of using a cam 
shaft, it uses actuators. This meand 30% smaller, lighter engines, and so 
far, 30% better fuel economy. Oh and also a third more power too. And 
that's only out of a Modified engine, not even one built just for this 
system. 

Brilliant.

#koenigsegg  ﻿
top_comment.author: Josh Schneider

comments.text:

comments.text:
the engines turn into garbage the second a hack mechanic gets hold of it 
and stuffs around with things he/she don't understand...
but yeah, I would be quite paranoid with this car (like I am with 928S that 
is so reliant on the timing belt, one piston goes, they all go AND all your 
valves... ) but if you really understand where there may be a problem, you 
can usually avoid it.
comments.author: Helena !

comments.text:
I am concerned about the reliability. Having physically linked all the 
distribution elements guarantees that, unless there's something broken, 
when a piston is up its valves are closed. But fully relaying on 
electronics, sensors and software, seems to be more prone to a collision 
between valves and pistons, and thus more engines turned into garbage...

top_comment.text: give this man a nobel prize!﻿

comments.text:
That's the problem, all you need to do is give it a quick zap of very high 
voltage and it's charged. It charges almost right away. They still haven't 
figured out a viable way to keep zaping the capacitors as the car drives 
down the road. Graphene capacitors weigh almost nothing as well. You could 
shave off all the battery weight in tesla model s, that's over 1000lbs 
which is substantial.
comments.author: William Stewart

comments.text: +William Stewart How do they charge?
comments.author: Timothy Thomas

comments.text:
+ThyBiding It's here already, graphene super capacitors are already 
developed. It's finding a way to charge them as you drive that is the 
challenge. Batteries are old school, out dated even. Graphene capacitors 
will replace them in the automotive world.
comments.author: William Stewart

comments.text:
Technology is there to leap what we already have. The politics behind 
keeping the status quo is another matter.
comments.author: John Burns

comments.text:
Oh ok I get what the two of you are saying, but by the time this tech is 
brought down to the level of the consumer don't you think that engines will 
have become far more energy efficient? I mean this video alone shows us 
what is possible. I agree that there will come a time where engines as they 
stand today in cars will become obsolete but that doesn't sound very 
realistic with cost and mass production of these concepts.
comments.author: Timothy Thomas

comments.text:
Micro turbines are in trucks and buses right now. They are the size of a 
very large can of beans and turn a generator at very high speed, like 
300,00 rpm. The waste heat can turn a small free-wheel piston (electric 
coils in the piston) Stirling engine/generator to provide electricity for 
vehicle ancillary duties - electric a/c, heating, power steering, etc. The 
Stirling may also have its own burner to operate from the fuel tank when 
the vehicle is stopped and the turbine is off.
comments.author: John Burns

comments.text:
+Timothy Thomas Jet engines come in many sizes.  Don't jump to 
conclusions.  Because of the way they work they make the most powerful and 
efficient engines if you can find a way to harness the heat.  When you use 
the heat to heat water and spin a generator it you have an extremely 
efficient turbine generator.  Take a look at the Walmart Turbine Truck.
comments.author: Atanas Tripzter

comments.text:
+Atanas Tripzter What? Jet engine? How does that even make sense? Where did 
you get that from?
comments.author: Timothy Thomas

comments.text:
+Timothy Thomas Odds are if manufacturers go with a generator type for cars 
they will be using a jet engine of some sort.
comments.author: Atanas Tripzter

comments.text:
Not really. Engines will most likely act as an alternator, charging the 
batteries of the car, maybe adding to the power of the car as a hybrid, 
acting as a back up etc.Taking on a smaller and smaller road as time goes 
on internal combustion engines will probably be around for another 40-50 
years.
comments.author: Timothy Thomas

comments.text:
Big Oil Money will keep internal combustion engines around as long as 
possible. Without the Automotive industries Oil companies will fail.

comments.text:
Batteries have progressed amazingly in 20 years. Far greater than in the

comments.text:
+RoMMeL1337ak47 The overwhelming advantages of electric traction is 
irrelevant to where the energy comes from.
comments.author: John Burns

comments.text:
+John Burns Well ofc, the electric train doesn't have to store it's energy 
on board, it has massive lethal power lines over head providing energy!

But roads don't! Why? Because it's expensive and very unsafe. So then you 
are back to carrying like 1.5 tons of batteries to replace a 100 liter fuel 
tank, and then the power to weight ratio goes way way below an IC engine 
and thus you get a fraction of the acceleration!
comments.author: RoMMeL1337ak47

comments.text:
Electric Commuter trains have acceleration a diesel train cannot come close 
to. They are preferred because of many obvious reasons, one is the 
acceleration clears a station and line quickly. IC engines cannot compete 
with electric motors for speed. Look at Top Gear and the RX8.
comments.author: John Burns

comments.text:
+RoMMeL1337ak47 I see your point... Ethanol is a temporary solution... I 
personally love the McLaren P1, the LaFerrari, and the Porsche 918, because 
it shows that super cars can be eco-friendly... Plus, on the addition that 
v8's are good, take the new Corvette z51 for example... it has 460 bhp, 440 
ft/lbs of torque, a beastly exhaust note, and it still has cylinder 
deactivation in it's 6.2 small block, and has been tested by Popular 
Mechanics to 30 highway MPG... although that being effected by the 
corvette's small weight, and it's efficient shape... Also, I love the Tesla 
model S... It shows that electric cars can really be feasible everyday, and 
even long-distance cars... What I think it needs is, like the Chevy Volt, a 
very small generator, wether it be powered by gasoline, ethanol, compressed 
natural gas, propane, even biomass... that will put it into the pure, 
long-distance car that tesla needs (even offer it as an option)... Sorry 
for rambling on and on, I just wanted to voice my opinion...
comments.author: Nathaniel Mathias

comments.text:
+John Burns Yes battery powered cars can be practical for a lot of people. 
But you just gotta remember, there are a lot of people out there, me 
included, that drive a vehicle because they like the way it pulls when you 
hit the gas pedal, the sound it makes, and the rubber it burns! Sure 
electric cars will take off when we get better means of storage, but as of 
now lets enjoy our internal combustion engines to their extent because I 
know I will! 

P.S.- I know that electric cars can be fast too, but as of now, not faster 
than IC engines...
comments.author: Mike Bender

comments.text: +inTHyper Do what?

efficiency so it's really really not a long term solution. It fails at

comments.author: RoMMeL1337ak47

comments.text:
Here is my theory for fuel efficiency... Give every car a big, 5L v8 with 
cylinder deactivation... You have huge amounts of torque for starting out 
and going up hills... Most smaller engines have to go at 3,000 or 3,500 
rpm, a 5.0 v8 goes at 800-1,000 rpm... Then, when you dont need that power, 
you can have a 2.5 V4 to cruse along... There.
comments.author: Nathaniel Mathias

comments.text:
+KevinHarper3DArtist  "If you think about cell phones 15 years ago, you

3-5 days. Cell phones haven't always had 5" HD displays and the internet,

comments.text:
+RoMMeL1337ak47 Battery powered cars are practical. The Tesla Model S 
proves that. The internal combustion engine will be moved to range extender 
duties. A part time engine - a generator.  I only see small. light, quiet 
and smooth valveless Wankels fitting that niche.

comments.text:
+John Burns We know that it is feasible, the question is if it battery 
powered cars are more practical and superior to the internal combustion 
powered cars, and the answer is no, and hell fucking no!
comments.author: RoMMeL1337ak47

comments.text:
+RoMMeL1337ak47 Tesla have proven that 100% battery power is feasible RIGHT 
NOW! The only thing lacking is the charging infrastructure. In New York 
City before WW1 there was 15,000 electric charging points. Batteries are 
getting better and better and combined with supercapacitors there is no 
need to have direct drive internal combustion engine cars. The IC engine 
will be used as a rage extender. The Wankel looks like replacing the piston 
engine car as the range extender. Mazda are working on laser ignition and 
direct injection which will improve matters brilliantly for this engine 
when used as range extender.

The Tesla can be transformed by a simple full, or partial battery change 
when newer better batteries are available. Try doing that with a car with 
an IC engine and auto trans.
comments.author: John Burns

comments.text:
+Grassroot Motorboat They will not be if we keep going on this 
way. Koenigsegg are a small company that are genuinely trying to improve a 
dog of an engine, the piston IC engine. I thank them for that. But the 
Stirling engine was perfected by NASA in 1986 for vehicle use. Look up NASA 
and the MOD II engine.  Big Corporate Auto and Big Oil didn't want to know. 
No weight gain over existing cars, improved fuel, torque, power, etc. Super 
smooth and quiet - and very clean running using continuous burn eternal 
combustion compared to dirty explosions in a cylinder. A Stirling is easily 
converted to
comments.author: John Burns

comments.text:
You improve old technology, new technology comes along, breakthrough and 
new designs. Repeat cycle
comments.author: Nate Adams

comments.author: Dusty Howlett

comments.text:
They have all the technical specs for that Saab somewhere, If you buy 
one... nevermind, they'd probably never let those specs get out to the 
public.
comments.author: Russabi von iBassur

comments.text: I want one!
comments.author: Stephen Nichelson

comments.text: +Dusty Howlett
comments.author: Philip Barton

captions.text:
CHRISTIAN VON KOENIGSEGG:
My name is Christian Von
Koenigsegg.
I'm 40 years old.

And for half of my life I've
been on the quest to be a

leader in the hypercar industry,
utilizing Swedish

design combined with visionary
technical solutions.

Our latest car, the Agera R, is
built in the old hangers of

a former Swedish fighter
jet squadron.

Their symbol, a ghost, is now
proudly painted on the back of
every Koenigsegg.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

CHRISTIAN VON KOENIGSEGG: So
now I'm going to show you

something which we are working
on for the future, which I

personally find very, very
interesting in many aspects.

So what this is, this is what
we call an actuator.
It's a Free Valve actuator.

Most of you who are familiar
with combustion engines and

especially car engines know
that there are camshafts

involved to move the valves
inside the cylinder head.

And these valves, they have been
controlled by camshafts

for the last 150 years or
something like that.

But it's very restrictive,
really, especially if you have

multi-cylinders and you want
to have a rev range to go

through with efficiency and
power because, when you have a

camshaft, you basically look
at all the cylinders in the

same line to do, pretty
much, the same thing.

There are coming systems now
which give some flexibility.

You can tweak the angle a little
bit, compared to the
crank of the engine.

And you can slide them sideways,
like Audi is doing
to shut off cylinders now.

So it's getting better and
better, but it's still very,
very restrictive.

You can think of the camshaft
like a broom, pretty much.

You hold it in your hands and
you push all the valves

simultaneously with
this broomstick.

What the Free Valve system
does is that each valve
becomes individual.

So if you think of the valves
like keys on the piano,

suddenly, instead of pushing all
the keys at the same time

with a broomstick, you can
actually play the keys with

your fingers, which is
the Free Valve idea.

And then, of course, the
engine can perform in a

completely different way than
being forced into a preset
pattern of combustion.

So what we're going to show
you here is this is like a

small cut out of a
cylinder head.
Here we have one valve.

Normally, there are two intake
valves and two exhaust valves.

And here is just a small
rig to run one of
these Free Valve actuators.

So basically, here you
have the valve.
Here you have the actuator.
It goes into it like this.

This is lubricated by engine
oil and pressurized by

pressurized air, which acts
like an air hammer
to move this out.

Then the engine oil makes sure
it stays stable and can lock
it in different positions.

And then air spring or a metal
spring pushes it back.

So we have individual control
over each valve, which brings
great benefit to the combustion
cycles in the engine.

So it's actually a snowballing
effect.

The engine becomes lighter,
smaller, cheaper, cleaner.

It can change the look of
the car in the end.

So it's a very, very interesting
technology that

I'm sure, one way or the
other, will conquer the
cylinder heads of the world.

So here we'll go into a little
bit of details how it works.

Urban, who is partly responsible
for this

development, will show you a
little bit what it looks like.

URBAN CARLSON: It's a very
simple control system.

We have one signal
for each valve.

And when we tell it to open,
it opens with a few
milliseconds delay.

And when we tell it to close,
it closes with, again, a few
milliseconds delay.

This it can do at very
high speeds, up to
20,000 RPM, if necessary.

CHRISTIAN VON KOENIGSEGG: The
same size of actuator is

actually good for a small
motorcycle engine revving

15,000 RPM and a truck engine
revving 2,500 RPM.

Because the motorcycle valve is
very light, so it takes the

same energy to drive it
backwards and forwards at

15,000 RPM as it takes to drive
a huge, heavy truck

valve backwards and forwards
at 2,500 RPM.

So it's very neat that the same
actuator basically covers

the need for all different
engine sizes.

So now we're running at
what kind of RPM here?

URBAN CARLSON: Well, here's
a little bit over idle.

CHRISTIAN VON KOENIGSEGG:
This is actually the
movement of the valve.

So you can see it
goes quickly up.
And then it stays flat.

It's like having a square
camshaft profile to make the
engine breathe really well.

If you would have a square
camshaft profile, it would

break immediately, because it
would jump off the edges and

would start hitting
the valve stem.
And it wouldn't work.

But with the Free Valve system,
you can actually open

any way you like and open really
fast, stay open flat,
and then drop down.

Here it's possible to see the
valve sequence as well.

That is a smooth curve, so it
doesn't hit the valve so you
create noise and wear.

URBAN CARLSON: This
is 3,000 RPM.

And you can see still a square
form of the valve curve.
This is 9,000 RPM.

CHRISTIAN VON KOENIGSEGG: So
this might just look like an
old Saab to you all.

And in fact, it is, apart
from one aspect.

That aspect is what you
see that's red here.

And that's the cylinder head,
which has been modified to

accommodate our Cargine
Free Valve system.

So basically what we've done
here is we've taken the

cylinder head apart, machined
out all the mountings and so

on for the camshafts, and
installed 16 Cargine Free
Valve actuators.

And then we have designed
a special valve cover.

Or it's not really
a valve cover.

It's more a lid containing
pressurized air channels and

pressurized oil channels
coming from
the engine oil side.

You can see the height of
this black cover here.

That's the same height as
the standard cylinder
head used to be.

So even when we retrofit it,
when it's not optimized for

space, it's anyway lower than
the standard cylinder head.

So the engine actually shrinks
and becomes lighter.

If we would have made a cylinder
head from scratch,

instead of retrofitting into an
existing cylinder head, it

would also become much narrower
and even lower.

And this whole section here,
which is a cover for where the

chain drive and for the camshaft
used to sit, would
disappear completely.

So the engine would also
become a lot shorter.

Basically, when you go from
a camshaft to Cargine Free

Valves, the size of a
four-cylinder engine becomes

just a little bit bigger
than the size of a
three-cylinder engine.

And then, of course, if you
cut away one cylinder to

maintain the power and torque
level you used to have in your

four-cylinder engine, then it
becomes really much smaller.

So this car here has been
running with Cargine Free

Valve system, winter
and summer, for the
last 2 and 1/2 years.

We've accumulated almost 60,000
kilometers, without any

failure whatsoever to the
Free Valve system.

It's just been upgraded with
our latest generation,

actuator generation 5, on both
the intake an exhaust side of
the engine.

And it's been tested at the
testing institute, called AVL,

with up to 20% improvement in
fuel efficiency so far.

And that's just the starting
point, I would say.

This is more a test field to
run for durability and for

cold starts, even in the winter,
down to minus 20
degrees Celsius.
But it's really exciting.

And it's, I think, one of the
few cars in the world that is

running with no camshaft
whatsoever.

When it's fully optimized, we're
expecting to have 30%

less fuel consumption, 30%
more torque, and 30% more

power, and, in an
average driving
cycle, 50% less emissions.

And that's without connecting
it to the possibility, which

is very interesting, which
is an air tank.

Given this valve technology, we
can actually recoup energy

while engine braking, by using
the engine as an air pump,

pumping up a tank with air,
getting air pressure there,

and then driving off only on
that air, using the engine as

a compressor or, let's
say, an air engine.

That compressed air can also
be used for boosting the

engine while using fuel to
have a really big, quick

spooling turbo which
consumes no energy.

So instead of storing energy
in the battery and like a

battery, we're using an
empty tank of air.

So that's the next step
of this technology.

But already, without that, it's
a huge benefit, compared
to normal camshafts.

This technology is not
yet in Koenigsegg.

And it's something, of
course, we might plan
to do for the future.

It will be another three, four
years out, before it's in any
production car.

And hopefully, the Koenigsegg
could be one of the first.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

title: The Future of the Internal Combustion Engine - /Inside Koenigsegg
